bullets.text: With shutdown ending, delayed jobs and inflation reports will resume, likely showing cooling labor demand; markets brace for data catch-up volatility.
Airlines warn widespread cancellations will persist post-shutdown; FAA staffing backlog and systems resets delay normalization; private aviation usage surged.

Tariff policy turbulence: specialty grocers face higher costs; White House exploring $2,000 tariff rebates; importers say court-ordered refunds feasible; U.S.-Switzerland negotiating slashing 39% tariffs.
U.S. maritime revival faces labor shortages; suspension of fees on Chinese vessels undercuts domestic shipbuilding economics, complicating industrial policy goals.
AI cycle intensifies: AMD guides 35% revenue CAGR on insatiable demand; hyperscalers dominate gains amid funding gaps and earnings skepticism; SoftBank trims Nvidia, stoking volatility.
Market breadth improving: Dow outperforms, signaling rotation beyond mega-cap AI leaders as investors seek laggards and cyclicals.
SNAP payment delays are denting sales at food and restaurant chains; Supreme Court pause extends uncertainty over back pay, pressuring lower-income consumption.
EU weighs law to phase out Huawei and ZTE gear, accelerating 5G rip-and-replace costs and deepening tech decoupling from China.
Israel’s government stability wobbles as key minister Ron Dermer resigns; security tensions persist with arrests after West Bank extremist attack.
Target’s broad price cuts signal intensifying retail price competition, aiding disinflation but pressuring margins across staples categories.
Drug pricing shifts: Eli Lilly rallies on volume-led growth despite price cuts; Amgen reports promising cholesterol trial results, reinforcing cardiometabolic pipeline momentum.
Rocket Lab posts record revenue and growing launch backlog, underscoring resilience of small-satellite launch demand despite broader space sector funding strains.
X5.1 solar flare prompts G4 geomagnetic storm watch, posing elevated risks to satellites, HF communications, and power grids.
U.S. incomes skew higher: about one-third of families now earn above $150,000, highlighting divergence with Europe’s stagnating growth.
New research: entangled diamond spins show quantum advantage; astronomers constrain “impossible” black holes; universal law may cap life’s growth rates.
